section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Ged Adamson
section-block.rac_book_summary: All Herb wants is to grow like his friend Muriel. But no matter what he tries, he never seems to get any taller! This narrative teaches children about comparing heights, and presents opportunities to explore collecting and graphing data.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children several kinds of tools that measure height (yard stick, measuring tape, ruler). Model how these tools are used to measure height and length.
Have children find an object in the room whose length is equal to one hand. Ask children to share the objects with the group and explain how they know they’re equal.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Want to Grow by Ged Adamson.
You know that Lala loves stories where characters measure things!
There is a question that I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one way Herb tries to grow taller?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: Pause to have children compare the heights of characters and objects in the book.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Muriel is getting taller! If Muriel is taller, are Herb and Muriel’s heights equal?
Why do you think Herb doesn’t like that Muriel is taller?
The tree has marks like a ruler!
What are Herb and Muriel using to measure?
Have you ever measured how tall you are? What measuring tool did you use? (MB)
Is Herb taller or shorter than the flowers by the wall? Who can point to the tallest flower on the page?
Why is Herb planting himself in the ground? What happens to flowers when you water them? (MB)
How did Herb make himself taller? Is his new hat taller than his shoes? Who can come up and look closer to check?
Herb grew! Muriel grew, too. Herb is taller, but is he taller than Muriel now? How can you tell?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one way Herb tries to grow taller?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use the Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He plants himself like a flower.
He has Muriel roll him like clay.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about growing taller.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Herb wear to make himself taller?
Have you ever wanted to be taller? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children have practiced comparing heights and lengths informally by sight and by nonstandard units. Learning to use a ruler is the next step! Although children are unlikely to correctly measure using a ruler, encourage them to practice lining up an object with the end of the ruler and noting what number it reaches.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk and Share

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We talk and share with others all the time, for lots of different reasons. We share information we’ve learned when we answer questions. We share our likes and dislikes, and ideas for games to play. We also share stories and memories with our friends. Going to school and being a friend involved a lot of talking and sharing. What can you share with us today?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread I Want to Grow by Ged Adamson. We will talk about how the characters share their thoughts.
Clifford loves to talk and to share his thoughts with his friends. He also likes to read stories and notice how characters share their thoughts.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Classification: Pause to discuss the height chart in the book as a type of graph.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Herb and Muriel are walking to school! Can you share how you got to school today? (MB)
Do you remember this tree from yesterday? What are Herb and Muriel using it to measure?
The marks on the tree are a type of graph. They show how tall Herb and Muriel are.
section.rac_body-text: Point out the labels on each mark.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This mark says December, and this one says May. Why? What can you tell about Herb and Muriel from reading this graph?
How did Herb get Muriel to try rolling him? He talked to her and shared his idea! When have you shared an idea with a friend? (MB)
Herb feels 10 feet tall. That’s as tall as three of you standing on each other’s shoulders! Does Herb feel big or small? Why do you think that?
What did Muriel not share with Herb? Why didn’t Muriel share that she also grew taller? (MB)
Sometimes, we have thoughts that could hurt others’ feelings. It is good to be honest, but sometimes it is important to keep some thoughts to yourself.

section.rac_body-text: Play a game. Create a “Yes I Do” side and a “No I Don’t” side. Give a prompt about likes and dislikes, such as Do you like chocolate? Give children time to decide and move to a side. Have children in each group say, Yes, I like ___ or No, I don’t like ___ . Encourage children to notice that the side with more children is the most popular answer, just like the tallest bar on a graph.
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell stories to explain their likes and dislikes.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: For preschoolers, talking and sharing often starts with recalling a recent event, such as what they did with their families over the weekend. It grows over time to sharing like interests with classmates. Model talking and sharing about your own experiences and preferences whenever possible. (Read & Patterson, 1980)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask two children to stand back to back and compare their heights. Then, invite other children to stand back to back, and invite the class to compare those children’s heights.

(Tune: “The More We Get Together”) The more we grow together
Together, Together
The more we grow together
The taller we’ll be!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread I Want to Grow by Ged Adamson.
Lala loves reading books that tell made up stories, like this book!
There are lots of ways to measure height. As we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can Herb and Muriel tell that they have grown?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversation with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Muriel is too big for her clothes! How can you tell?
Have you ever grown too big for your clothes? What happened then? (MB)
Why is Herb standing on books? Does it make him shorter or taller? Does Muriel need to stand on anything to reach? Why not?
Lots of animals come to visit while Herb waits in the ground. Which animal is taller, the worm or the dog? What about the worm and the bee? How can you tell?
Muriel is making things out of clay. Have you ever made something out of clay? What? (MB)
Is the jar of clay taller or shorter than the clay snake? How can you tell?
Muriel notices that Herb has grown. How can she tell? What is she using to compare his height?
We made a chart of all of your heights earlier this year. Do you think you have grown since then? How can we find out?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can Herb and Muriel tell that they have grown?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use the Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Muriel is too big for her clothes.
Muriel can see over the fence.
They mark their heights on a tree.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about tools that measure height.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do Herb and Muriel mark on the tree?
Herb and Muriel use a tree to mark their h________ (heights).
Herb and Muriel use a tree to mark their heights.
How else could you tell if you have grown?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: You have been speaking with children and adding to their vocabulary all year. You naturally support them in speaking in longer, more creative sentences. Encourage children to extend their phrases by modeling how to do that. If a child says, I like it, you can respond, I like that red toy too because it’s so big and shiny!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about Herb’s discoveries in the Big Book. What did Herb discover about growing taller? Did you discover anything about growing this week?
Pick out a book children have not yet read. Ask children to investigate it: How many pages are there? Is it taller or shorter than I Want to Grow? What shape is it?

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read What We Have Learned. It is an informational poster about what we have learned this year.
I Want to Grow and What We Have Learned each focus on growing up. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show I Want to Grow Big Book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How have we changed?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and talk about height.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What have you learned about yourself this year? What have you learned about your friends? (MB)
Look at the picture! Who can come up and point to the friend who is the shortest?
What do you think the boy in the picture is investigating?
What else did we discover about animals? (MB)
Do you think the bird in the picture is tall or short? Why?
This year, we discovered how to make the things we build taller and shorter! Do you remember how? Tell us one way. (MB)
We planted seeds this year. Do you remember? Did our plants grow taller or shorter?

section.rac_body-text: Provide various arts and crafts materials. Have children draw, paint, or make a picture of the favorite thing they learned this year. They can use ideas from the Big Chart, or something they learned outside of school. When children are finished, invite them to describe their “favorite thing” to the class. Encourage them to use descriptive language as they share.
Provide a writing prompt about what children learned this year, and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: While many children will start to use more complex sentences in preK, multilingual learners might still use one-word answers as they continue to explore a new language. Encourage children to expand their sentences using favorite or familiar topics. Provide frames for complex sentences and guide children to use the frames to extend their thoughts.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 3: Growing Up

section-block.rac_body-text: Give each child a sticky note. Ask, Who is your favorite character from I Want to Grow—Muriel or Herb? Invite children to draw or write their answer on a sticky note. Then have children place their sticky notes on a chart or board to create a bar graph. Ask, Why do you like this character? Encourage children to give their answer with detail. Compare results: Which character is most popular?
Invite children to dance and sing to the PreK On My Way™ theme music. Encourage them to start low to the ground, and grow tall as they dance. How fast did you grow?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read I Want to Grow one more time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches true information. Which is it?
We have learned many ways we have changed since the beginning of the year! When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How has Herb changed at the end of the book?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together. We will act out parts of the story and work together to make a graph.
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Classification: Create two columns on a chart: Yes and No. Have children make a bar graph by coming up and placing a sticky note in the correct column as you ask, Did Herb’s idea work?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Herb plants himself like a flower. Let’s pretend to plant ourselves! Look up at all the tall flowers.
Did Herb’s idea work? Who can come up and place a sticky note for No?
Muriel rolls Herb like clay. Let’s roll ourselves back and forth.
Did it work? Who can come up and place a sticky note for No?
Herb tries to make himself grow! Can a person make themselves grow? How do you know? (MB)
Did it work? Who can come up and place a sticky note for No?
Herb wears tall shoes. Let’s pretend to walk in tall shoes! Stand up very tall and step high!
Did it work? Who can come up and place a sticky note for No?
Herb decides to go to bed and wait. Let’s all pretend to sleep.
Did it work? Who can come up and place a sticky note for Yes?
Did most of Herb’s ideas work, or did most not? How can you tell?
Will Herb still try to find ways to grow taller? Why not?
How has Herb changed at the end of the book?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then, ask several children to share with the group.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He doesn’t worry about growing anymore.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how they have changed since the beginning of the year.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Herb grow taller or shorter at the end of the book?
Do you think Herb will keep growing and changing? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Graphing data that children are invested in increases their interest in classification and in math as a whole. Favorite characters from a book and their own heights are just two examples of relevant and engaging content for children to graph. Help children list other topics that can be easily graphed.
